case_title: C.I.R., R.T.O., MULTAN vs Messrs SHAH SONS PAKISTAN (PVT.) LTD., MULTAN
respondant: Messrs SHAH SONS PAKISTAN (PVT.) LTD., Multan

accussed_details.name: Messrs SHAH SONS PAKISTAN (PVT.) LTD.
allegation: Illegal input tax adjustment on steel products, lubricants, and grease
Adjustment of input tax using fake/flying invoices

complaint_summary: The appellant alleged that the respondent claimed inadmissible input tax adjustments on steel products, lubricants, and grease, and used fake/flying invoices for tax adjustments.
investigation_summary: The assessing officer issued show-cause notices under sections 8(1)(a), 11(3), and 73 of the Sales Tax Act, 1990, and scrutinized sales tax returns and invoices. The respondent provided supporting documents, but the assessing officer deemed them insufficient.

S.T.A._No.18/LB_of_2016.facts: Input tax adjustment on steel products, lubricants, and grease disallowed under section 8(1)(a) of the Sales Tax Act, 1990.
S.T.A._No.18/LB_of_2016.department_position: Adjustment disallowed as it violated section 8(1) and related S.R.Os.
S.T.A._No.18/LB_of_2016.respondent_position: Claimed input tax based on valid invoices for taxable activities.
S.T.A._No.18/LB_of_2016.CIR(A)_decision: Allowed input tax adjustment, stating it was not in the negative list and supported by valid records.
S.T.A._No.18/LB_of_2016.tribunal_decision: Upheld CIR(A)'s decision, finding no evidence of non-taxable activity or inclusion in the negative list.

S.T.A._No.19/LB_of_2016.facts: Input tax adjustment of Rs.3,833,585/- challenged as based on fake invoices.
S.T.A._No.19/LB_of_2016.department_position: Claimed non-compliance with section 73 of the Sales Tax Act, 1990.
S.T.A._No.19/LB_of_2016.respondent_position: Provided complete records to prove compliance with section 73.
S.T.A._No.19/LB_of_2016.CIR(A)_decision: Annulled the order-in-original, finding allegations of tax fraud unsubstantiated.
S.T.A._No.19/LB_of_2016.tribunal_decision: Upheld CIR(A)'s decision, confirming compliance with section 73 and rejecting allegations of fake invoices.

legal_arguments: Prosecution argued adjustments violated section 8(1)(a) of the Sales Tax Act, 1990 and related SROs.
Defense argued adjustments were based on valid invoices and products were used for taxable activities.
key_issues: Compliance with section 73 of the Sales Tax Act, 1990

legal_terms.Input Tax Adjustment: A mechanism allowing taxpayers to deduct tax paid on purchases from tax payable on sales.
legal_terms.SRO: Statutory Regulatory Order issued under legislative authority.

words_and_phrases.Flying Invoices: Invoices issued without actual transactions to evade taxes.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of illegal input tax adjustments and use of fake invoices by the respondent. The tribunal upheld the CIR(A)'s findings, dismissing the appeals due to lack of evidence supporting the allegations.
